dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know how annoying online returns can be, right? Like, you send something back, and then you just wait forever for your refund.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know how annoying online returns can be, right? Like, you send something back, and then you just wait forever for your refund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, yeah, absolutely! It's the worst, especially when you need that money back to, like, buy the *right* thing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, yeah, absolutely! It's the worst, especially when you need that money back to, like, buy the right thing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, there's this new startup, Refundly – previously called Returnly, which is kinda confusing – that's trying to fix that payment delay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, there's this new startup, Refundly - previously called Returnly, which is kinda confusing - that's trying to fix that payment delay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, interesting! So how do they, um, tackle that? Do they just give you your money back super fast?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, interesting! So how do they, um, tackle that? Do they just give you your money back super fast?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Kinda! They issue instant store credit. So, you decide you don't want an item, and boom, credit for another purchase.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Kinda! They issue instant store credit. So, you decide you don't want an item, and boom, credit for another purchase.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A San Francisco-based startup called Returnly is seeking to solve at least a portion of the headachenamely, the payment delayby issuing instant store credit when you decide you dont want an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Oh, instant store credit! That makes sense. And they just launched with like, nine million in new funding, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, instant store credit! That makes sense. And they just launched with like, nine million in new funding, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly! Series B, led by Craft Partners. And get this, Alex Levchin, the PayPal co-founder who runs Affirm, is involved.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly! Series B, led by Craft Partners. And get this, Alex Levchin, the PayPal co-founder who runs Affirm, is involved.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly announced on Wednesday that it has raised $19 million in a Series B funding round, led by venture capital firm Craft Ventures and with participation from Max Levchin, the PayPal cofounder who currently runs Affirm.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, so some big names backing them. But how do they, um, manage the risk? Like, what if you don't actually send the item back?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, so some big names backing them. But how do they, um, manage the risk? Like, what if you don't actually send the item back?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's the cool part! They assess your risk, and they can offer instant credit to 60% of customers without you even mailing the item first.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the cool part! They assess your risk, and they can offer instant credit to sixty percent of customers without you even mailing the item first.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company says that by assessing a shoppers risk, it can offer store credit to 85% of customers on the spot, without first requiring that the item has been received or even put in the mail.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, so I don't even have to ship it? That's, like, a game-changer!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, so I don't even have to ship it? That's, like, a game-changer!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Think of that foundation example in the article. Wrong shade, instant credit, bought the right one and a lipstick.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Think of that foundation example in the article. Wrong shade, instant credit, bought the right one and a lipstick.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The first return it processed came from a customer who spent $75 on foundation, sight unseen, and wound up with the wrong shade for her skin tone. She was issued instant store credit, which she then used to buy the foundation in a different shade, in addition to throwing in a lipstick.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And that's where the retailers win, right? It's not just cash back; it's credit they'll likely spend *more* of.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that's where the retailers win, right? It's not just cash back; it's credit they'll likely spend more of.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly offers store credit, rather than cash, in the hope that shoppers will spend the amount they are credited and then some. It seems that the companys customers have done just that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely! They say five out of ten customers order a second item before even shipping the first back, and they outspend the original by 13%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely! They say five out of ten customers order a second item before even shipping the first back, and they outspend the original by thirteen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nine in ten have ordered a second item before they even shipped the first unwanted item back, the company says. Theyre likely to outspend the original size of their order, too, by 23%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's a huge incentive for stores! So, Refundly charges merchants for this, I assume?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a huge incentive for stores! So, Refundly charges merchants for this, I assume?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It also charges merchants an annual subscription fee.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, a cut on each transaction and an annual subscription fee. They've processed almost $300 million in returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, a cut on each transaction and an annual subscription fee. They've processed almost three hundred million dollars in returns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It has processed close to $200 million in returns in the last three years, taking a cut on each transaction. It also charges merchants an annual subscription fee. ... It also took out a line of credit earlier this year that enables it to finance $300 million in returns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but back to the risk. If they're giving credit *before* an item is returned, what happens if it never shows up?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but back to the risk. If they're giving credit before an item is returned, what happens if it never shows up?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they do assume that risk. But they can, uh, nudge customers via email or make it easier to return with printed labels or pickups.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they do assume that risk. But they can, uh, nudge customers via email or make it easier to return with printed labels or pickups.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Returnly then assumes the risk that a product is never returned... In such an event, says Vilar, it can nudge a customer over email or try to make a return easier by sending a printed return label in the mail, for example, or scheduling the pickup of an item.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's really about leveraging data and making the whole process frictionless. It's like Affirm or Klarna but for returns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, it's really about leveraging data and making the whole process frictionless. It's like Affirm or Klarna but for returns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Most notably, companies like Affirm and Klarna frequently offer easy loans at checkout, with interest rates ranging from zero and going well into the double digits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And with online purchases being four times more likely to be returned than in-store, they're tapping into a massive market.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And with online purchases being four times more likely to be returned than in-store, they're tapping into a massive market.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Online purchases are three times more likely to be returned than those made in a physical store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. It’s a win-win, I guess. Retailers get revenue, consumers get instant gratification. It's that "network effect" they talk about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. It's a win-win, I guess. Retailers get revenue, consumers get instant gratification. It's that network effect they talk about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The retailer gets a revenue-generating opportunity while the consumer gets instant gratification. ... Our whole business model is predicated on the network effect, says Vilar.
